Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research: Foundations of Hierarchical Full-Duplex Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop foundational principles for hierarchical wireless network design by leveraging full-duplex transmissions in both access and wireless backhaul. Full-duplex is most promising at shorter ranges, and hence is fortuitously aligned with the predicted dominant access range in future networks. Furthermore, larger full-duplex ranges are feasible in infrastructure-to-infrastructure links, and hence are well suited for backhaul links. While full-duplex is well-aligned with the key elements of hierarchical networks, our current design principles are largely developed for half-duplex transmissions which is the basis for all current networks. With that in mind, this project will address both theory and protocols for hierarchical full-duplex networks by looking at: (1) data-driven signal models for self-interference caused by the node's own transmission to its own receiver, (2) theoretical foundations for scheduling and routing that leverage both self-interference and multi-hop interference cancellation; and (3) protocols and prototypes for network scale full-duplex resource management.

Full-duplex breaks one of the basic design constraints in current wireless networks, all of which are either half-duplex in time or frequency; it will therefore rewrite wireless networking fundamentals. Further, with emphasis on realizable networks using extensive Rice University's programmable testbeds, the project will impact the next-generation of wireless networks via its corporate partners. Finally, the project team will establish a unique inter-university education and research program, which will include joint advising and collaborative advising and leverage the team's complementary expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

In this multi-university collaborative project, our overarching goal was to develop foundational principles for hierarchical wireless network design by leveraging full-duplex transmissions in both access and wireless backhaul. Full-duplex is most promising at shorter ranges, and hence is fortuitously aligned with the predicted dominant access range in future networks. Furthermore, larger full-duplex ranges are feasible in infrastructure-to-infrastructure links, and hence are well suited for backhaul links. While full-duplex is well-aligned with the key elements of hierarchical networks, our current design principles are largely developed for half-duplex transmissions which is the basis for all current networks.

The project goals were to develop data-driven signal models for fullduplex to facilitate information-theoretic analyses and foundations for network-scale resource allocation.

The project delivered many new technologies to advance the area of full-duplex and address some of the most challenging bottlenecks in the adoption of full-duplex. We highlight the following advances

1.  Shroff and his team develped low-complexity scheduling mechanism for full duplex communication with “cut through routing:" Cut through routing allows the wireless network to operate as if it were a wireline network (almost without any interference). This allows significant improvements in network capacity. 

2  Shroff and his colleagues developed a completely way of providing  Low-Feedback Wireless multicast, developed via a novel anonymous-query based rate control, which approaches the optimal throughput with a constant feedback overhead independent of the number of receivers.This resolves the scaling issue which has prevented multi-cast deployments from becoming a reality. 

3. Shroff and his team devloped protocols for fully bi-directional full duplex communications. This has been a breakthgough in both PHY layer and MAC layer technology to further improve upon the gains of full duplex communications.

4. Via collaborative research between Shroff (OSU) and Sabharwal (Rice) the PIs developed new scheduling schemes for multi-antenna systems with full duplex capability, which allowed a marriage of multi-antenna and full duplex systems. The fundamental limitation that was overcome here was to develop simple scheduling algorithms that rely on limiited feedback in the system rather thna using complete channel information to determine which users to serve. 

5. Shroff and Sabharwal worked on developing new solutions to achieve low latency and high reliability in  MIMO systems. A natural design choice to maximize reliability and minimize retransmission is to select the lowest allowed target error rate. However, the overall latency is the sum of queueing latency and retransmission latency, hence choosing the lowest target error rate does not always minimize the overall latency. Thus, this work aims to minimize the overall latency by jointly designing the target error rate and transmission rate adaptation, which leads to a fundamental tradeoff point between queueing and retransmission latency. 

The overall team also developed the first massive MIMO full-duplex (SoftNull and JointBull) and in the process, also developed first massive MIMO full-duplex that does not require any new analog components. This scalable design enables new uses of a large number of antennas in massive MIMO systems, beyond the initial imagined uses. Second, the team developed a novel method to build full-duplex networks which eliminates inter-node interference by reusing the cyclic prefix duration in OFDM systems. Third, the team developed a suite of protocols that enable full-duplex with multi-user beamforming (a key ingredient of 5G and next-gen WiFi systems). Fourth, we developed a virtual full-duplex system that unlike FDD, has physically bidirectionality in both bands, and transmissions are allocated to the bands according to whether they correspond to download or upload traffic. The “download data channel” carries data originating from the AP and that data’s associated reversed-direction acknowledgements, and viceversa for the “upload data channel.” Fifth, we developed virtual Multiple-Input Single-Output (vMISO) systems distributing multi-antenna diversity capabilities between a sending and a cooperating node. vMISO has the potential to vastly improve wireless link reliability and bit error rates by exploiting spatial diversity. Co-PI Knightly’s team presented the first design and experimental evaluation of vMISO triggers (when to invoke vMISO rather than traditional transmission) in Wi-Fi networking environments.

Broader Impacts: 

The research results have been published in peer-reviewed journals and conferences. The PIs have given several talks at various universities and companies that have highlighted the key contributions of the project. PI Shroff arranged and moderated a panel on full duplex communications at Mobihoc 2014 (where PI Sabharwal was also a panelist) and also gave a series of lectures 2014 Lipari School on "Network Analysis, Design and Optimization”, in July in Italy.

Shroff founded the IMACCS workshop at OSU (2016-2019), where different aspects of wireless networking research were explored with university and industry participants. 

Shroff has develop lectures and project assignments for a wireless course cross-listed between ECE and CSE at OSU that has a significant project component. Students are given assigments and encouraged to design wireless networks taking into account new technologies like Full Duplex and multi-user MIMO.
